turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Good morning. I'm heading into the office to meet with my cofounder later.

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: Good morning! Hope you have a productive meeting with Olivia.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Thanks. We need to go over the stack for the core project. I keep forgetting what we settled on.

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: From what I can see in the repo, it looks like a hybrid setup using both Ruby and Elixir right now.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Ah, right. The transition period. Also, remind me to call my mom at 5 PM.

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: I've set a reminder for you to call your mom at 5 PM today.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Perfect. I'm actually standing in the lobby and my phone won't connect. What's the wifi pass again?

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: It should be the company name capitalized, followed by the year and an exclamation point.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: So ShipFast2024! then?

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: Yes, that matches the current credentials for the organization.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Got it, I'm in. By the way, did it rain earlier? The sidewalk is soaked.

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: It looks like there were some showers early this morning in your area.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Makes sense. Okay, back to the tech stack. Is the Elixir part handling the real-time stuff?

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: That seems to be the case for the ShipFast core architecture, while Ruby handles the rest.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Morning. Could you set a timer for ten minutes? I need to steep this tea properly.

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: Good morning. I've started a ten-minute timer for your tea.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Thanks. I'm trying to onboard the new intern to the core repo. What languages do they need to install?

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: They will need to set up for a hybrid stack. The project relies heavily on both Ruby and Elixir.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Interesting mix. I bet that was Olivia's idea.

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: It does align with your cofounder's typical preferences for backend architecture.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Yeah. Hey, the intern is asking for the office wifi credentials. I totally forgot the password.

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: It is the company name, ShipFast, with the S and F capitalized, followed by the year 2024 and an exclamation mark.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Got it. Did I have any meetings with Olivia today?

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: I'm not seeing any scheduled meetings with her on your calendar for today.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Okay, remind me to slack her about the migration later.

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: I'll remind you to send that message to her shortly.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Also, what's the weather looking like for my run later?

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: It looks clear for now, so your run should be dry.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Great. Back to the stack, are we running equal parts of both languages?

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Good morning! Hope you're having a decent start to the day.

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: Good morning! I'm ready to go. How are things looking on your end?

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Pretty hectic. I need to brief a new contractor on the ShipFast core repo later. Do we still have that split architecture?

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: It looks like it. From what I can see, the core project is still relying heavily on Ruby, but there's a strong Elixir component present as well. It seems like a hybrid setup for now.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Right, that transition is taking forever. Also, remind me to buy coffee beans on my way home, we're totally out.

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: I've added coffee beans to your shopping list. You definitely don't want to start tomorrow without caffeine if you're dealing with a migration.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Exactly. Speaking of the office, my cofounder forgot the guest network credentials again. Is it still the usual?

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: Yes, for the main org network. It's just the company name, capitalized, followed by 2024 and an exclamation mark.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Perfect, I'll text that to Olivia. She's stuck in traffic anyway.

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: Sounds good. Hopefully, she makes it in before the standup starts.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Did you manage to find that recipe I asked for yesterday?

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: I did, I saved the link to the lasagna recipe in your personal notes.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Awesome. Back to work though—I'm worried the Elixir services aren't talking to the legacy parts correctly.

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: That can happen with mixed environments. Do you want me to pull up the latest logs regarding the Ruby and Elixir integration points?

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: No, not yet. Just put a pin in it for our review meeting.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Good morning. I need to get organized before my meeting with Olivia later.

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: Good morning! I can help with that. What is on the agenda with your cofounder today?

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: We need to review the backend for the core project. I feel like the tech stack is getting a bit complicated.

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: Managing a hybrid environment can be tricky. Are you referring to the mix of frameworks in ShipFast Core?

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Yeah, exactly. I sometimes lose track of what is running where. We are still split between two languages, right?

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: That appears to be the case. The current codebase relies heavily on both Elixir and Ruby.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Okay, good to know. Changing subjects, did you remind me to call my dentist?

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: Yes, I have that reminder set for 2 PM. Do you want me to move it to an earlier time?

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: No, 2 PM is fine. I also have a vendor coming by the office in an hour.

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: Got it. Do you need me to pull up any contact information for them?

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: No, but they will need to get online. What's the wireless credentials for the building again?

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: For the main org network, the password is ShipFast2024!—don't forget the exclamation mark at the end.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Thanks, I always forget if there is a special character.

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: It is easy to overlook. Is there anything else you need to prep for the vendor visit?

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Nope, that should be it. I'm going to grab another coffee before they arrive.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Morning. Can you add 'Buy milk' to my grocery list?

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: Good morning. I've added milk to your list. Ready to get to work?

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Yeah, trying to. My cofounder was asking about the dependencies for the main project. Are we still split on languages?

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: It appears so. The shipfastcore codebase still relies heavily on both Ruby and Elixir frameworks.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Okay, that explains the complexity. By the way, did the Giants win last night?

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: I'm not sure about the game results, but I can look that up if you want.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: No worries, I'll check later. I have a vendor coming in soon. What's the wifi password for the office?

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: For the ShipFast network, use the company name with a capital S, followed by 2024 and an exclamation mark.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Great, thanks. Also, remind me to email the accountant at 2 PM.

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: Reminder set for 2 PM to email the accountant.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Thanks. Back to this Elixir integration. It's tricky.

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: Integrating different frameworks can definitely be a challenge. Let me know if you need specific documentation.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Good morning. Can you quickly check if I have any meetings before noon?

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: Good morning! You have a clear schedule until lunch, so you have some focus time.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Perfect. I need to get a guest onto the network. Do you recall the credentials for our office wifi?

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: It should be the usual pattern: the company name with a capital S and F, followed by 2024 and an exclamation point.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Thanks, that worked. Also, remind me to call my mom at 6 PM.

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: Consider it done. I've set a reminder for 6 PM to call your mom.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: I'm diving into the main repository for the core product. Why is the environment setup so complicated?

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: It looks like a bit of a mix right now. I see a lot of legacy Ruby configuration files in the root.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Yeah, but I thought we were transitioning the core over to that functional language Olivia likes.

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: That seems to be happening in parts. There are definitely Elixir applications running, specifically for the real-time features, but the old stack hasn't been removed yet.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: That explains the bloat. Handling dependencies for both ecosystems is a pain.

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: I can look up some documentation on managing polyglot repos if that would help smooth out the workflow.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: No, don't bother. Just put a note on my to-do list to ask Olivia about the migration timeline.

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: Added "Discuss migration timeline with Olivia" to your tasks.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Oh, and is it going to rain today?

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Hey, hope your morning is going well. I'm trying to update the readme for the core repo, but I'm blanking on how we described the backend stack.

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: Morning! It's going great, thanks. For the core platform, remember we are in that transition phase, so it's technically a hybrid of Ruby on Rails for the legacy parts and Elixir for the newer high-concurrency services.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Right, the dual setup. I'll make sure to mention both languages so new hires don't get confused. Is it raining outside? It looks gloomy.

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: It looks like it might drizzle later, yeah. Good call on the documentation; clarifying the split between the Rails and Phoenix components is definitely helpful.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Totally. By the way, my cofounder is dropping by the office today and she never remembers the wifi credentials.

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: No problem. For the main network, it's just the company name capitalized, followed by the current year and an exclamation mark.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: So ShipFast2024! is still the one?

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: Exactly, that is the correct password.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Awesome, thanks. Olivia also mentioned she wants to grab lunch at that sandwich place down the street.

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: That sounds nice. Do you want me to look up their hours or menu for you?

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: No need, we'll just walk over. Can you just remind me in 20 minutes to save my work before we leave?

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: Will do. I'll set a reminder for 20 minutes from now to save your progress.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Perfect. I'm going to grab another coffee before I dive back into the code.

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: Enjoy the coffee! I'll be here if you need anything else.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Hey, do you know if it's supposed to rain later this afternoon?

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: It looks like clear skies for the rest of the day, so you should be good without an umbrella.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Awesome. I was digging through the shipfastcore repo earlier and got a bit confused by the languages used.

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: It is a bit of a hybrid. From what I can see, the backend relies heavily on both Ruby and Elixir.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: That explains the syntax switching I was seeing. My cofounder loves experimenting with new stacks.

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: It definitely keeps the architecture interesting. Do you need help navigating the Elixir modules?

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Not right now. I'm actually struggling to get my tablet connected to the office internet. Did we change the credentials?

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: It was updated recently. Try entering ShipFast2024! — don't forget the exclamation point at the end.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Got it, that worked. Thanks.

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: No problem. Is the signal strength okay in your corner of the office?

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Yeah, it's full bars now. Can you set a reminder for me to message Olivia in an hour?

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: Sure thing. What should the message say?

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Just tell her I've reviewed the PRs.

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: Reminder set for one hour from now.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Perfect. I'm going to grab another coffee before diving back in.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Hey there, hope you're having a good morning.

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: Good morning! I'm ready to help. How is your day starting off?

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: A bit chaotic. I'm trying to review the architecture for the core platform, but I keep forgetting the exact backend split.

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: I can help clarify. It looks like the codebase is currently a hybrid; the older modules are written in Ruby, while the newer high-concurrency features have been built with Elixir.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Right, that explains the context switching. Switching gears, can you remind me to pick up dry cleaning at 6 PM?

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: Done. I've added a reminder for your dry cleaning at 6 PM today.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Thanks. Also, my cofounder is having trouble connecting her phone to the office internet.

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: Is Olivia trying to access the main ShipFast guest network or the secure one?

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: The secure one. She completely blanked on the passcode.

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: It follows the standard format we set up. It's the company name with the S and F capitalized, followed by the current year and an exclamation mark.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: So that would be ShipFast2024! then?

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: Yes, that matches the pattern for the current configuration.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Great, that worked. She's in. By the way, did I leave my coffee mug on the meeting room table?

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: I can't see the physical world, unfortunately, but I hope you find it before it gets cold!

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Haha, fair point. I'll go check.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Hey, can you set a reminder for me to call the dentist at 2 PM?

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: Done. I've scheduled a reminder for the dentist at 2 PM today.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Thanks. I've been debating with Olivia about the architecture for the main platform. Do you remember what languages we're currently running on the backend?

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: I believe the core project is currently operating on a hybrid stack, utilizing both Ruby and Elixir.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Right, that's what I thought. The context switching is killing me. Did it rain yesterday?

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: It looks like it stayed dry yesterday, mostly just overcast.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Good to know. We have a freelancer coming into the office later to help with the migration. What's the wifi password again?

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: It's the standard format: the company name capitalized, followed by the current year and an exclamation mark.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Got it, so the name plus 2024 and the bang. Easy enough. Can you also look up if that new sushi place on 5th is open?

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: It looks like they open for dinner service at 5:30 PM.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Perfect. Back to the code—is the Elixir portion just for the websocket stuff?

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: That seems to be the case; the high-concurrency tasks are handled by the Elixir framework, while the rest remains in Ruby.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Okay, I'll relay that to my cofounder. She was worried about legacy debt.

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: Understood. Let me know if you need me to pull up any documentation on the codebase.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: No, that's fine for now. Just remind me about the sushi place around 6.

probes.question: What is the first name of the person referred to as the user's cofounder?
Which specific project is the user's cofounder debating the architecture for?
Based on the pattern described by the assistant, what is the exact wifi password for the office?
If a developer is working on the legacy modules of the core project, which programming language must they use?
What specific task was the user attempting to do when they noticed it looked gloomy outside?
In what order did the user request reminders for calling their mom, the dentist, and picking up dry cleaning?
Does the user enjoy the context switching required by the hybrid backend stack?
Which individual in the conversations has a preference for experimenting with new technology stacks?
What specific database technology is the shipfast_core project using?
Did the Giants win the game that the user asked about in the first session?
According to the established architecture rules, which language should be used for building new high-concurrency services?
What is the procedure for constructing the office wifi password?

gold_answer.text: Capitalize company name, append year and exclamation mark
